texts.definition: Locations in game worlds which signify game state changes directly related to the progress of some goal.
markups: <style="Definition">Locations in game worlds which signify game state changes directly related to the progress of some goal.</style>

Goals in many games consist of moving between different places in game worlds or levels. <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> act as places which indicate having reach such points, or points along the way.

All <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Racing%20Games">Racing Games</link></style>, such as the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sega%20Rally%20series">Sega Rally series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Out%20Run">Out Run</link></style>, make use of <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> by having goal lines for completing the race. Racing goal in other games, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Assassin's%20Creed%20series">Assassin's Creed series</link></style> use <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> in the same fashion. They are also used in some of the team versus team levels in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style>.

Capture the Flag variants of multiplayer first-person shooters, such as in some variants of Quake and Unreal Tournament, have certain areas where the enemy flag has to be delivered for the team to score.

<style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> are typically used to create <style="Link"><link="traverse">Traverse</link></style> goals (including <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="herd">Herd</link></style> goals) or <style="Link"><link="backtracking-levels">Backtracking Levels</link></style> (by having a <style="CurrentLink">Check Point</style> at the furthermost point of a <style="Link"><link="levels">Level</link></style>). They are also used indicate how to achieve <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, notice how far players have gotten in <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="continuous-goals">Continuous Goals</link></style>. By doing these things, they affect <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. The naturally form a form of <style="Link"><link="collections">Collection</link></style> but this can be made more explicit and part of the game mechanics if not all <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> need to be reached or players have choices on which order to reach the <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> can be placed anywhere that makes sense to specific goals in a game, but <style="Link"><link="safe-havens">Safe Havens</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style> are examples of game features that quite naturally suit themselves as <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> as well (<style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> can of course also be modified so they act as <style="Link"><link="save-points">Save Points</link></style> also - so the patterns can affect each other). By their placements, they can draw players together in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>, e.g. to get many to <style="Link"><link="arenas">Arenas</link></style>, and thereby offer a design solution for getting players co-located in games with large <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>.

Otherwise, <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> are typically <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>. Regardless, the location of <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> can be indicated locally or from a distance by <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>. They can also be indicated on <style="Link"><link="mini">Mini-maps</link></style> to make them easier to reach.

<style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> typically work against <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> since most they are <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>

<style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> are <style="Link"><link="supporting-goals">Supporting Goals</link></style> that provide both <style="Link"><link="point-interest-indicators">Point of Interest Indicators</link></style> and a type of <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="goal-indicators">Goal Indicators</link></style>. They can serve as <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> and can denote <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style>, or make places into <style="Link"><link="strategic-locations">Strategic Locations</link></style> simply by their own existence. By their placement they can make players engage in <style="Link"><link="game-world-exploration">Game World Exploration</link></style> as part of trying to achieve some other goal.

When reaching <style="CurrentLink">Check Points</style> are used to achieve <style="Link"><link="area-control">Area Control</link></style>, they create <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals.
